column2: THE SWINEHERD

column2: There was once a poor Prince.
column3: There was once a poor Prince.

column2: He possessed a kingdom which, though small, was yet large enough for him to marry on, and married he wished to be.
column3: He possessed a kingdom which, though small, was yet large enough for him to marry on, and married he wished to be.

column2: Now it was certainly a little audacious of him to venture to say to the Emperor's daughter, 'Will you marry me?' But he did venture to say so, for his name was known far and wide.
column3: Now it was certainly a little audacious of him to venture to say to the Emperor's daughter, 'Will you marry me?' But he did venture to say so, for his name was known far and wide.

column2: There were hundreds of princesses who would gladly have said 'Yes,' but would she say the same?
column3: There were hundreds of princesses who would gladly have said 'Yes,' but would she say the same?

column2: Well, we shall see.

column2: On the grave of the Prince's father grew a rose-tree, a very beautiful rose-tree.
column3: On the grave of the Prince's father grew a rose tree, a very beautiful rose tree.

column2: It only bloomed every five years, and then bore but a single rose, but oh, such a rose!
column3: It only bloomed every five years, and then bore but a single rose, but oh, such a rose!

column2: Its scent was so sweet that when you smelt it you forgot all your cares and troubles.
column3: Its scent was so sweet that when you smelt it you forgot all your cares and troubles.

column2: And he had also a nightingale which could sing as if all the beautiful melodies in the world were shut up in its little throat.
column3: And he had also a nightingale which could sing as if all the beautiful melodies in the world were shut up in its little throat.

column2: This rose and this nightingale the Princess was to have, and so they were both put into silver caskets and sent to her.
column3: This rose and this nightingale the Princess was to have, and so they were both put into silver caskets and sent to her.

column2: The Emperor had them brought to him in the great hall, where the Princess was playing 'Here comes a duke a-riding' with her ladies-in-waiting.

column2: And when she caught sight of the big caskets which contained the presents, she clapped her hands for joy.

column2: 'If only it were a little pussy cat!' she said.

column2: 'It is more than pretty,' said the Emperor, 'it is charming!'

column2: But the Princess felt it, and then she almost began to cry.

column2: 'Ugh! Papa,' she said, 'it is not artificial, it is REAL!'

column2: 'Ugh!' said all the ladies-in-waiting, 'it is real!'

column2: 'Let us see first what is in the other casket before we begin to be angry,' thought the Emperor, and there came out the nightingale.

column2: It sang so beautifully that one could scarcely utter a cross word against it.

column2: 'Superbe! charmant!' said the ladies-in-waiting, for they all chattered French, each one worse than the other.

column2: 'How much the bird reminds me of the musical snuff-box of the late Empress!' said an old courtier.

column2: He painted his face brown and black, drew his cap well over his face, and knocked at the door.

column2: 'Good-day, Emperor,' he said.

column2: 'Can I get a place here as servant in the castle?'
column3: 'Can I get a place here as servant in the castle?'

column2: 'Yes,' said the Emperor, 'but there are so many who ask for a place that I don't know whether there will be one for you; but, still, I will think of you.
column3: 'Yes,' said the Emperor, 'but there are so many who ask for a place that I don't know whether there will be one for you; but, still, I will think of you.

column2: Stay, it has just occurred to me that I want someone to look after the swine, for I have so very many of them.'
column3: Stay, it has just occurred to me that I want someone to look after the swine, for I have so very many of them.'

column2: And the Prince got the situation of Imperial Swineherd.
column3: And the Prince got the situation of Imperial Swineherd.

column2: He had a wretched little room close to the pigsties; here he had to stay, but the whole day he sat working, and when evening was come he had made a pretty little pot.
column3: He had a wretched little room close to the pigsties; here he had to stay, but the whole day he sat working, and when evening was come he had made a pretty little pot.

column2: All round it were little bells, and when the pot boiled they jingled most beautifully and played the old tune--
column3: All round it were little bells, and when the pot boiled they jingled most beautifully and played the old tune-

column2: 'Where is Augustus dear? Alas! he's not here, here, here!'
column3: 'Where is Augustus dear? Alas! he's not here, here, here!'

column2: But the most wonderful thing was, that when one held one's finger in the steam of the pot, then at once one could smell what dinner was ready in any fire-place in the town.

column2: Now the Princess came walking past with all her ladies-in-waiting, and when she heard the tune she stood still and her face beamed with joy, for she also could play 'Where is Augustus dear?'

column3: 'I will have ten kisses from the Princess,' answered the Swineherd.

column2: 'You would have nothing to do with a noble Prince; you did not understand the rose or the nightingale, but you could kiss the Swineherd for the sake of a toy. This is what you get for it!' And he went into his kingdom and shut the door in her face, and she had to stay outside singing--
